Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Voltage-sensitive Dyes based on Mesoscopic Electron Transfer

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The research proposed herein is to create a new class of voltage sensitive dyes to measure cell membrane potentials and to track neuronal activity. Containing an electron donor-acceptor pair separated by a spacer, the dyes are based on the electric-field dependence of electron transfer, which competes with fluorescence emission and converts changes in electric fields to changes in fluorescence intensity. This type of dyes is unique in that their fluorescence intensity has wavelength-independent voltage response, and therefore all their emitted photons may be collected for voltage detection. This is in sharp contrast to existing voltage-sensitive dyes in which only a small portion of emitted photons are useful, and may therefore lead to photon counts hundreds of times larger and improve signal-to-noise ratio in measurements by more than one order of magnitude. Guided by both theoretical calculations and optical characterization, the aim is to synthesize dyes with sub-microsecond time response, high voltage sensitivity, and large fluorescence quantum yield, so that they can facilitate multi-site optical tracking of neuronal activity with sub-millisecond time resolution and sub-micrometer spatial resolution. Furthermore, based on this general voltage-sensing mechanism, more novel optical voltage probes can be developed, such as two-photon-absorbing voltage-sensitive fluorescent dyes that would allow for three-dimensional brain imaging and probes based on fluorescent proteins.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the three years funded by the award from NSF, we have developed a new class of dyes called graphene quantum dots (graphene QDs) that are primarily made of carbon, an abundant element on Earth, and have conducted preliminary studies on their photo-physical properties. Comparing with other dyes, the graphene QDs are unique in many aspects. For example, they can absorb all visible light, making them a novel class of light absorbers for light-to-electricity conversion (as in solar cells). When excited by light, the QDs can emit luminescence through different mechanisms (i.e., fluorescence  and phosphorescence), making them potentially useful as a new type of optical sensors for external physical and chemical changes.

We have preliminarily investigated the potential of the graphene QDs in fabrication of solution-processable solar cells as an alternative to those made of silicon. Even though the solar cells we have made are not yet as efficient, we have identified several parameters that are essential for future improvement, and currently we are optimizing these parameters to achieve better energy conversion efficiency. The abundance of the constituent elements of the graphene QDs and their environmental friendliness make them attractive candidates for sustainable use of carbon for energy.

Another direction we are pursuing is to use the graphene QDs to optically track voltage changes across nerve cell membranes during neuronal activities. The goal is to develop a new tool to help understand how information is processed by central nerve systems. Since photo-excited graphene QDs can emit light through different channels (i.e., fluorescence  and phosphorescence) and that the two channels have different emission rates, we currently are investing the possibility of using external electrical voltages to alter the ratio of the two channels so that we can use their intensity ratio as a measure for the voltages. This could lead to novel optical sensors to track neuronal activities which involve changes in electrical voltages across nerve cell membranes.

The graphene QDs we have developed are a new addition to carbon materials, which have played important roles in modern society (e.g., in pencil lead, gas masks, electrodes, etc.). They not only have novel properties that could lead to new applications, but also could serve a model system to understand more complex carbon materials so that we can further improve the efficiency of  complex carbon materials.
